Line 364: Line 364:
The army stated on 17 February 2011 it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] and former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], as well as steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News - Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
The army stated on 17 February 2011 it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] and former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], as well as steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News - Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>

=== 18 February â Friday of Victory ===
+
=== 18 February â Friday of Victory and later ===
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
On 18 January, influential Muslim cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], who arrived in Egypt after decades of exile in [[Qatar]], led the "Victory Day" Friday sermon in Tahrir Square attended by hundreds of thousands of people, while men who appeared Qaradawi's guards barred [[Wael Ghonim]] from joining him on stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-protest-hero-Wael-Ghonim-barred-from-stage/Article1-663996.aspx |title=Egypt protest hero Wael Ghonim barred from stage |publisher=Hindustan Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses |title=Egypt revolution unfinished, Qaradawi tells Tahrir masses |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/1832138.html |title=Mass protests as Egyptians mark "Victory Day" | Arabic region | Trend |publisher=En.trend.az |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
On 18 January, influential Muslim cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], who arrived in Egypt after decades of exile in [[Qatar]], led the "Victory Day" Friday sermon in Tahrir Square attended by hundreds of thousands of people, while men who appeared Qaradawi's guards barred [[Wael Ghonim]] from joining him on stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-protest-hero-Wael-Ghonim-barred-from-stage/Article1-663996.aspx |title=Egypt protest hero Wael Ghonim barred from stage |publisher=Hindustan Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses |title=Egypt revolution unfinished, Qaradawi tells Tahrir masses |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/1832138.html |title=Mass protests as Egyptians mark "Victory Day" | Arabic region | Trend |publisher=En.trend.az |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
